1.verse: I, Solomon, David’s son and Israel’s king, pass on to you these proverbs—a treasury of wisdom—

2.verse: So that you would recognize wisdom and value discipline; that you would understand insightful teaching

3.verse: And receive wise guidance to live a disciplined life; that you would seek justice and have the ability to choose what is right and fair.

4.verse: These proverbs teach the naive how to become clever; they instruct the young in how to grow in knowledge and live with discretion.

5.verse: The wise will pay attention to these words and will grow in learning, and the discerning will receive divine guidance,

6.verse: And they will be able to interpret the meaning of a proverb and a puzzle, the twists and turns in the words of the wise and their riddles.

7.verse: A strategic translation decision has been made to respect the historical situation of this book. In its original context, Proverbs is practical wisdom passed down from parents (especially fathers, see chapters 1–9) to young men who are preparing to enter a life of adult responsibilities: family, business, community leadership, and so on. Because of this relational aspect, we have retained masculine references when appropriate and have used more inclusive language when that was the intention of the original author. It is our greatest hope that God will use this work to remind fathers of the profound place they have in nurturing, instructing, and guiding the next generation. Let us begin. The worship of the Eternal One, the one True God, is the first step toward knowledge. Fools, however, do not fear God and cannot stand wisdom or guidance.

8.verse: So, my son, pay attention to your father’s guidance, and do not ignore what your mother taught you—

9.verse: Wear their wisdom as a badge of honor and maturity, as fine jewelry around your neck.

10.verse: My son, should your less honorable peers pressure you to do what is wrong, you should be strong enough not to go along.

11.verse: If they should say, Evildoers: Come on! Everyone, hide and let’s wait to see whom we can beat to a pulp. We’re going to jump some unsuspecting chumps for no reason at all.

12.verse: We’ll have our way with them, and when we’re through, there will be nothing left, as if their bodies were swallowed whole by the grave’s dark pit.

13.verse: We’ll take whatever we want—all their wealth and their fancy clothes— and when we’re through, we’ll have piles of their treasure for our own.

14.verse: You have to join us; forget about God. We’re going to rake in the goods, and we’ll share all we take!

15.verse: My son, do not join them; keep well away from their violent, destructive paths.

16.verse: For they run right away, every time, to do wrong, and they are thirsty for blood.

17.verse: You see, it makes no sense to bait the net and set the trap while the bird is watching,

18.verse: But these hiding in the shadows and waiting to spill innocent blood are really just hastening their own destruction! By giving in to their sinful desires, they set themselves up to be ambushed.

19.verse: This is what happens to everyone who tries to profit by violence; violence will eventually rob them of their very lives.

20.verse: Each generation faces strong peer pressure to follow the world’s ways, especially during adolescence. That pressure can twist an innocent young man inside out until he is nearly unrecognizable to those close to him. Once gang mentality takes over, that young man could easily find himself in unexpected and troublesome situations. Wisdom calls, and her voice is clear: Remember your parents’ instruction. Avoid violence and violent people. If you don’t, violence will find you. There’s another voice in town. It belongs to Lady Wisdom, who calls out in the street. She cries out in the town square,

21.verse: At the city gates, in the noisy city streets, you can hear her speaking over the racket.

22.verse: Lady Wisdom: You simple, naive people, how long will you love your feeble ways? You simpletons, how long will you enjoy making fun of what you don’t understand? You fools, how long will you hate learning what truly matters?

23.verse: Turn to me and receive my gentle correction; Watch and I will pour out my spirit on you; I will share with you my wise words in order to redirect your lives.

24.verse: You hear, but you have refused to answer my call. My hands reached out, but no one noticed.

25.verse: All my advice, all my correction, all have been neglected— you wanted nothing of them.

26.verse: So I will be the laughter you hear when misfortune comes, and it will come. I will be the mocking sound when panic grips you—

27.verse: When panic comes like a stormy blast, when misfortune sweeps in like a whirlwind, when sorrow and anguish weigh you down.

28.verse: This is when they will call on me, but I will not respond; they will be frantic to find me, but they won’t be able.

29.verse: Because they despised knowledge of my ways, and they also refused to respect and honor the Eternal,

30.verse: Because they rejected my advice and turned down my correction,

31.verse: They will surely get what’s coming to them: they’ll be forced to eat the fruit of their wicked ways; they’ll gorge themselves on the consequences of their choices.

32.verse: You see, it’s turning away from me that brings death to the simple, and it’s self-satisfaction that destroys the fools.

33.verse: But those who listen to me now will live under divine protection; they can rest knowing they are out of harm’s way.

1.verse: My son, if you accept what I am telling you and store my counsel and directives deep within you,

2.verse: If you listen for Lady Wisdom, attune your ears to her, and engage your mind to understand what she is telling you,

3.verse: If you cry out to her for insight and beg for understanding,

4.verse: If you sift through the clamor of everything around you to seek her like some precious prize, to search for her like buried treasure;

5.verse: Then you will grasp what it means to truly respect the Eternal, and you will have discovered the knowledge of the one True God.

6.verse: The Eternal is ready to share His wisdom with us, for His words bring true knowledge and insight;

7.verse: He has stored up the essentials of sound wisdom for those who do right; He acts as a shield for those who value integrity.

8.verse: God protects the paths of those who pursue justice, watching over the lives of those who keep faith with Him.

9.verse: With this wisdom you will be able to choose the right road, seek justice, and decide what is good and fair

10.verse: Because wisdom will penetrate deep within and knowledge will become a good friend to your soul.

11.verse: Sound judgment will stand guard over you, and understanding will watch over you as the Lord promised.

12.verse: Wisdom will keep you from following the way of evildoers, of those who twist words to pervert the truth,

13.verse: Of those who reject the right road for a darker, more sinister way of life,

14.verse: Of those who enjoy evil and pursue perverse pleasures,

15.verse: Of those who journey down a crooked path, constantly figuring out new ways to trick and deceive others.

16.verse: Wisdom will pluck you from the trap of a seductive woman, from the enticing propositions of the adulteress

17.verse: Who chose to leave the husband of her youth, to forget her sacred promises to her God;

18.verse: For her house is on the road that leads to death, and her path goes down to the shadowy pit.

19.verse: Those who go to her will never return; they will never again find their way back to true life.

20.verse: As for you, you should walk like those who are good and keep to the paths of those who love justice,

21.verse: For those who live right will remain in the land and those with integrity will endure here.

22.verse: But not the wicked; they will be forced out and banned from this promised land, and those who deal in deceit will be plucked up like weeds.

1.verse: My son, always remember what I have taught you; keep my instructions dear to your heart.

2.verse: If you do, they will be your guide to a long, healthy, prosperous life.

3.verse: Stay focused; do not lose sight of mercy and truth; engrave them on a pendant, and hang it around your neck; meditate on them so they are written upon your heart.

4.verse: In this way, you will win the favor of God and others, and they will think well of you.

5.verse: Place your trust in the Eternal; rely on Him completely; never depend upon your own ideas and inventions.

6.verse: Give Him the credit for everything you accomplish, and He will smooth out and straighten the road that lies ahead.

7.verse: And don’t think you can decide on your own what is right and what is wrong. Respect the Eternal; turn and run from evil.

8.verse: If you depend on Him, your body and mind will be free from the strain of a sinful life, will experience healing and health, and will be strengthened at their core.

9.verse: Pay tribute to the Eternal in all of your affairs. Honor Him with the best of what you make.

10.verse: That way you will prosper to the fullest and have plenty of food to eat and wine to drink.

11.verse: My son, do not ignore the Eternal’s instruction or lose heart when He steps in to correct you;

12.verse: Because the Eternal proves His love by caring enough to discipline you, just as a father does his child, his pride and joy.

13.verse: God knows well what He is doing. He has established rewards for living wisely: A happy, long life. A good reputation. Guidance when you need it most. Health. Success. Even, dare we say, fatherly discipline. These are just a few of the benefits accompanying God’s wisdom. How fortunate are those who discover Lady Wisdom and those who understand her ways!

14.verse: For her worth is greater than the most expensive prize you could win. Her profit is greater than the finest thing you could buy.

15.verse: No gem is more precious than she is— your most extravagant desire doesn’t come close to her.

16.verse: She holds the secret of a long life in one hand and riches and fame in her other hand.

17.verse: Her ways are pleasant; all of her pathways are peaceful.

18.verse: She is like a tree that produces a satisfied life for anyone who can wrap their arms around her; happiness waits for any who hold her tightly.

19.verse: It was by wisdom that the Eternal fashioned the earth and by understanding that He designed the heavens.

20.verse: Through His knowledge, the deep was divided into seas and sky, and the clouds understood when to let down the morning dew.

21.verse: My son, never lose sight of God’s wisdom and knowledge: make decisions out of true wisdom, guard your good sense,

22.verse: And they will be life to your soul and fine jewelry around your neck.

23.verse: Then each one of your steps will land securely on your life’s journey, and you will not trip or fall.

24.verse: Your mind will be clear, free from fear; when you lie down to rest, you will be refreshed by sweet sleep.

25.verse: Stay calm; there is no need to be afraid of a sudden disaster or to worry when calamity strikes the wicked,

26.verse: For the Eternal is always there to protect you. He will safeguard your each and every step.

27.verse: Do not withhold what is good from those who deserve it; if it is within your power to give it, do it.

28.verse: Do not send your neighbor away, saying, “Get back with me tomorrow. I can give it to you then,” when what he needs is already in your hand.

29.verse: Make no plans that could result in injury to your neighbor; after all, he should be more secure because he lives near you.

30.verse: Avoid fighting with anyone without good reason, especially when no one has hurt you; you have nothing to fight about.

31.verse: Do not envy someone who profits at the expense of others or copy any of his tyrannical ways,

32.verse: For crooked people are detestable to the Eternal, but those with integrity receive His counsel.

33.verse: His curse lingers over the wicked and their families, but He forever favors residence of those who do what is right.

34.verse: God treats the arrogant as they treat others, mocking the mockers, scorning the scornful, but He pours out His grace on the humble.

35.verse: In the end, the wise will receive honor, but fools will face humiliation.

1.verse: It’s perfectly natural to envy those who are successful. It’s even natural to want to imitate them. But what about those who’ve gotten ahead by doing the wrong thing? Sometimes it seems crime does pay, the good do die young, and the wicked do have more fun. But it only appears this way; it is not reality. In reality the success of wrongdoers is short-lived. God is against them, and their house is built on the sand. Even if it seems to be a grand house, it will soon come crashing down. Gather, children, to hear your father’s instruction. Pay close attention so you will understand,

2.verse: For I am passing down to you important precepts. Do not abandon these valuable life lessons.

3.verse: Back when I was young—the very image of my father, and yet from my mother’s view, still her only boy—

4.verse: My father, with his years of experience, became my teacher. Father: Son, grab on to every word I say to you—hold them close— stay true to my instructions as you live, and they will serve you well.

5.verse: Whatever it takes to gain Wisdom, do it. To gain understanding, do it! Never forget this! Never stray from what I am telling you.

6.verse: If you don’t forsake Lady Wisdom, she will protect you. Love her, and she will faithfully take care of you.

7.verse: Gaining sound judgment is key, so first things first: go after Lady Wisdom! Now, whatever else you do, follow through to understanding.

8.verse: Cherish her, and she will help you rise above the confusion of life— your possibilities will open up before you— embrace her, and she will raise you to a place of honor in return.

9.verse: She will provide the finishing touch to your character—grace; she will give you an elegant confidence.

10.verse: Hear my words, my son, and take them in; let them soak in so that you will live a long, full life.

11.verse: I have pointed you in the way of wisdom; I have steered you down the path to integrity.

12.verse: So get going. And as you go, know this: with integrity you will overcome all obstacles; even if you run, you will not stumble.

13.verse: Tighten your grip around wise advice; don’t let it slip away. Protect Wisdom, for without her, life isn’t worth living.

14.verse: Do not start down the road of the wicked— the first step is easy, but it leads to heartache— do not go along the way of evildoers.

15.verse: Stay away from it; don’t even go past it— and if you find yourself anywhere near it, turn your back and run as far as you can in the opposite direction.

16.verse: For evildoers are so twisted they cannot sleep unless they have caused harm; they’ll lie awake all night until they figure out a way to cause someone to stumble.

17.verse: For they feed on evil the way most eat bread; they drink violence the way most guzzle wine.

18.verse: Yet the way of those who do right is like the early morning sun that shines brighter and brighter until noon.

19.verse: Evildoers travel a dark road because they love to hide their deeds in darkness; they can’t see the perils ahead that cause them to stumble.

20.verse: Fathers have a crucial role in instructing their sons. It’s easy and natural to teach children about some things: how to take care of a car, how to hit a ball, or how to mow the lawn. But what about deeper things, the kinds of things that make life worth living? These are much harder. They must not be left for someone else to do. Paul wrote, “And, fathers, do not drive your children mad, but nurture them in the discipline and teaching that come from the Lord” (Ephesians 6:4). Instructing children in the ways of God is crucial work. My son, pay attention to all the words I am telling you. Lean in closer so you may hear all I say.

21.verse: Keep them before you; meditate on them; set them safely in your heart.

22.verse: For those who discover them, they are life. They bring wholeness and healing to their bodies.

23.verse: Above all else, watch over your heart; diligently guard it because from a sincere and pure heart come the good and noble things of life.

24.verse: Do away with any talk that twists and distorts the truth; have nothing to do with any verbal trickery.

25.verse: Keep your head up, your eyes straight ahead, and your focus fixed on what is in front of you.

26.verse: Take care you don’t stray from the straight path, the way of truth, and you will safely reach the end of your road.

27.verse: Do not veer off course to the right or the left; step away from evil, and leave it behind.

1.verse: My son, stay focused; listen to the wisdom I have gained; give attention to what I have learned about life

2.verse: So you may be able to make sensible judgments and speak with knowledge.

3.verse: You see, the lips of a seductive woman speak honey-sweet words; they are smooth like oil and enticing.

4.verse: But in the end, she is bitter, turning the stomach and rotting the soul; she cuts as deep as a double-edged sword.

5.verse: She leads you down a path that can only end in death; her steps lead eventually to the grave.

6.verse: She does not travel the road to life and truth. She follows a wandering path— a rocky, pit-filled road that twists and turns—and she doesn’t even know it.

7.verse: So, my children, listen to me. Do not stray from my advice.

8.verse: Stay away from her, far away from her path; don’t even go near her door

9.verse: Unless you are ready to hand over your reputation to someone else, unless you want to spend the rest of your years at the mercy of some cruel person.

10.verse: If you do, strangers will help themselves to your wealth, and everything you have worked hard to acquire will end up in someone else’s hands.

11.verse: Your life will end with groanings of remorse, of opportunities missed, and your flesh and bones will be eaten up with sorrow, regret for worthless efforts.

12.verse: Then you’ll say, “Why did I hate being taught? Why did I turn my back on correction?

13.verse: I disregarded all that my teachers said to me; I turned my ear away from my instructors!

14.verse: Now I am on the edge of complete and utter ruin in the midst of the community.”

15.verse: People are easily seduced, especially men. Everyone is vulnerable to sexual sin at some point or another, and history is strewn with the wreckage that results when the path of adultery is followed: bitterness, death, instability, loss, ruin. Time and again, these are the consequences of violating God’s instruction. Here’s what you should do to be satisfied: go home and drink in the pleasures of your own cistern, your wife; enjoy the sweet, fresh water that has been there all along, flowing from your own well.

16.verse: Take care. Should your own springs, your body, be freely shared? Should your streams of water satisfy anyone in the streets? Absolutely not!

17.verse: They should be kept pure for you and you alone, not for sharing with strangers.

18.verse: May your fountain, your sex life, be blessed by God; may you know true joy with the wife of your youth.

19.verse: She who is lovely as a deer and graceful as a doe— as you drink in her love, may her breasts satisfy you at all times.

20.verse: My son, why get caught up in some other woman and embrace the breast of a stranger?

21.verse: Wisdom recognizes the beauty of sexual intimacy. After all, God designed us as sexual beings. But for physical intimacy to retain the beauty of its design, it must be shared wisely. It is meant to be shared with someone who is your own. In marriage two become one (Genesis 2:24), so they belong together and belong to each other. In that safe place of belonging, one finds fulfillment. So a husband or a wife must partake only of the partner’s body and love. To seek intimacy elsewhere is foolish. You see, the Eternal sees our ways before Him. He watches every move we make and knows where those paths lead.

22.verse: The wicked will be snared by their own wrongdoing. Their flaws will tie their own hands, and they will be dragged through life by the cords of their sins.

23.verse: Because they have no discipline, their spirits die and their bodies will soon follow; because they are immensely foolish, they wander lost and confused.

1.verse: My son, if you will risk your family’s future to put up collateral for the debts of an acquaintance, if you seal a commitment with a handshake to someone without first knowing the value of his word,

2.verse: Then your words may well be the trap that snares you, and your promise may seal your fate. You can’t be sure to whom you hitched your future.

3.verse: So, my son—save yourself! Here’s what you need to do: go to that person who became your master with a handshake, humble yourself, and plead your case.

4.verse: Do not sleep; don’t even rest your eyes until you deal with this.

5.verse: Get out as quickly as possible, as a gazelle runs from the hand of the hunter, as a bird takes off from the grip of the fowler.

6.verse: Take a lesson from the ant, you who love leisure and ease. Observe how it works, and dare to be just as wise.

7.verse: It has no boss, no one laying down the law or telling it what to do,

8.verse: Yet it gathers its food through summer and takes what it needs from the harvest.

9.verse: How long do you plan to lounge your life away, you lazy fool? Will you ever get out of bed?

10.verse: You say, “A little sleep, a little rest, a few more minutes, a nice little nap.”

11.verse: But soon poverty will be on top of you like a robber; need will assault you like a well-armed warrior.

12.verse: Laziness is not just a bad habit; it’s a threat—a clear and present danger. Since the beginning, God has made us in His image to create and tend His good creation. In other words, God has made us to work. It is in our spiritual DNA. We must do it in order to be who God made us and to fight off the threats of poverty and want. God has also created the Sabbath as a space for us to rest, of course, just as He rested on the seventh day. Someone who struts around taking advantage of unsuspecting souls and deceiving others is to be avoided.

13.verse: With a wink of his eye, a quick shuffle of his feet, and a slight gesture with his hand, he signals his roguish treachery.

14.verse: With a warped mind and twisted heart, he constantly looks for his own gain at others’ expense, causing friction everywhere he goes.

15.verse: But you watch: his actions will bring sudden disaster! In an instant, his life will be shattered, and there will be nothing to save him.

16.verse: Take note, there are six things the Eternal hates; no, make it seven He abhors:

17.verse: Eyes that look down on others, a tongue that can’t be trusted, hands that shed innocent blood,

18.verse: A heart that conceives evil plans, feet that sprint toward evil,

19.verse: A false witness who breathes out lies, and anyone who stirs up trouble among the faithful.

20.verse: So, my son, follow your father’s direction, and don’t forget what your mother taught you—

21.verse: Keep their teachings close to your heart; engrave them on a pendant, and hang it around your neck.

22.verse: Their instruction will guide you along your journey, guard you when you sleep, and address you when you wake in the morning.

23.verse: For their direction is a lamp; their instruction will light your path, and their discipline will correct your missteps, sending you down the right path of life.

24.verse: They will keep you far from the corrupted woman, away from the smooth talk of a seductive woman.

25.verse: Do not lose yourself in desire for her beauty or let her win you over with her painted eyes,

26.verse: For you can buy a harlot with a loaf of bread, but sex with another man’s wife will cost you your life.

27.verse: Can you carry fire right next to your body and keep your clothes from burning?

28.verse: Can you walk over fiery coals and keep your feet from blistering?

29.verse: Take another man’s wife, and you will find out— whoever touches her will be found guilty.

30.verse: People don’t despise a thief who only steals to fill his hunger;

31.verse: Still if they catch him, he must repay seven times over— he could end up losing everything he owns!

32.verse: By contrast only a fool would commit adultery since by his action he loses not only his possessions but also his own life.

33.verse: He will suffer injury and be disgraced; dishonor will leave a permanent mark on his life.

34.verse: For jealousy sparks a husband’s rage— when he gets his revenge, he’ll show no mercy.

35.verse: He will not be paid off or appeased; no bribe or gift will set things right.

1.verse: My son, live according to what I am telling you; guard my instructions as you would a treasure deep within you.

2.verse: Stay true to my directives, and they will serve you well; make my teachings the lens through which you see life.

3.verse: Bind cords around your fingers to remind you of them; meditate on them, and you’ll engrave them upon your heart.

4.verse: Say to Lady Wisdom, “My sister”; recognize that understanding is your best friend,

5.verse: And they will keep you from the arms of another woman— protect you from the enchantress who entices men into her bed.

6.verse: People are forgetful, so we must be reminded constantly of Wisdom and her ways. We don’t always need to hear something new; often we just need to be reminded of what is true. In these proverbs wisdom is found when one not only knows what is right, but acts on that knowledge. Foolishness, on the other hand, means a lack of understanding and wrongdoing. One day I was at the window of my house, looking out through my lattice shutters,

7.verse: And there among the usual crowd of the gullible people I spotted a naive young man.

8.verse: He was going down the street near the corner where she lived—that mysterious and evil woman— taking the road that led directly to her house.

9.verse: At the end of the day, as night approached and darkness crept in,

10.verse: I saw her! A woman came out to meet him. She was dressed for temptation and devious with her affections.

11.verse: Here’s what I know about her: she is loud and obnoxious, a rebel against what is proper and decent. She’s always on the move—anxious to get out of the house and

12.verse: Down the street; at times in the open, at others lurking around every corner.

13.verse: As I am watching them, she grabs him and kisses him, then shamelessly tells him:

14.verse: The Immoral Woman: It was my turn to offer a peace offering, and today I paid my vows,

15.verse: So now I come to see you. I really want to be with you, and what luck! I have found you!

16.verse: You’ll be impressed. I have decorated my couch, laid colorful Egyptian linens over where we will be together,

17.verse: And perfumed the bed with exotic oils and herbs: myrrh, aloes, and cinnamon.

18.verse: Come in, and we will feast on love until sunrise; we will delight ourselves in our affections.

19.verse: You don’t need to worry; my husband is long gone by now, away from home on a distant journey.

20.verse: He took a bag of money with him, so I don’t expect him home until next month.

21.verse: It worked! She enticed him with seductive words, seduced him with her smooth talk.

22.verse: Right away he followed her home. He followed her like a bull being led to the slaughter, Like a fool caught in a trap

23.verse: (that is, until an arrow punctures his liver), Like a bird flying straight into a net. He had no clue his life was at stake; everything was about to change.

24.verse: This is why it is so important that you listen to me, my sons, and pay attention to all I am telling you.

25.verse: Do not let your mind wonder about her ways; do not lose yourself and drift down her path,

26.verse: For she’s claimed one life after another, victim after victim, too many to count.

27.verse: Her house is the gateway to the grave; every step toward her is a step toward death’s dark chamber.

1.verse: Isn’t Lady Wisdom calling? Listen; don’t you hear the voice of understanding crying out?

2.verse: She’s taken her stand at the highest place in the city, at the crossroads where everyone can see her.

3.verse: There, and at the gates, at the entrance to the city, right in front of the city doors she cries out:

4.verse: Lady Wisdom: O people! I am calling to you; I have a message for all humanity.

5.verse: You gullible people, acquire insight. You naive ones, cultivate a heart that truly understands.

6.verse: Listen, for I am about to tell you of unparalleled excellence and beauty; what I am about to say will set things right.

7.verse: I will only speak the truth; I despise evil, so it will not pass through my lips.

8.verse: Everything I say promotes justice; not one word is crooked, and nothing is distorted.

9.verse: Each and every word is straight talk to perceptive people, upright and honest to knowledge-seekers.

10.verse: Accept my correction as being more valuable than your prized possession, authentic knowledge more valuable than pure gold.

11.verse: You see, no gem is more precious than Lady Wisdom— your most extravagant desire doesn’t come close to her.

12.verse: Lady Wisdom: I make my home with prudence; I obtain knowledge and sound judgment.

13.verse: If you respect the Eternal, you will grow to despise evil. I despise wretched, vile talk and ways of pride and arrogance.

14.verse: Good counsel is mine, and also true wisdom. I am understanding, and strength belongs to me.

15.verse: It’s because of me that kings wield power and authorities decree what is right.

16.verse: It’s because of me that leaders and their agents govern and all judge according to what is right.

17.verse: I love those who love me; those who search hard for me will find me.

18.verse: Riches and honor are the benefit of following me; so are lasting wealth and justice.

19.verse: My reward is better than gold, even the purest gold; and my profit is greater than the highest quality silver.

20.verse: I follow the way of right living. Follow me along the path to find justice;

21.verse: I’m ready to meet those who love me, bestow true riches upon them, and fill up their lives until their treasuries overflow.

22.verse: The Eternal created me; it happened when His work was beginning, one of His first acts long ago.

23.verse: Before time He established me, before the earth saw its first sunrise.

24.verse: I was born before the deep existed, before any springs poured out their water,

25.verse: Before the mountains were placed on their foundations, before the hills rolled across the land— yes, before all this, I was brought forth.

26.verse: When the earth was yet unformed and the fields were not yet nestled beneath the wind— even before the first dust of the earth—

27.verse: When He created the heavens, I was there. When He drew a circle in the deep, dividing the oceans and the sky, I was there.

28.verse: I was there when He established the sky. I was there when the springs in the deep were fortified;

29.verse: I witnessed Him lay down the shore as a boundary and put limits on the water And determine the foundations of the earth.

30.verse: All this time I was close beside Him, a master craftsman. Every day I was His delightful companion, celebrating every minute in His presence,

31.verse: Elated by the world He was making and all its fine creatures; I was especially pleased with humanity.

32.verse: So now listen to me, my children: those who live by my ways will find true happiness.

33.verse: Pay attention to my guidance, dare to be wise, and don’t disregard my teachings.

34.verse: The one who listens to me, who carefully seeks me in everyday things and delays action until my way is apparent, that one will find true happiness.

35.verse: For when he recognizes and follows me, he finds a peaceful and satisfying life and receives favor from the Eternal.

36.verse: But heed my warning: the one who goes against me will only hurt himself, for all who despise me are playing with fire and courting death.

1.verse: Lady Wisdom has built her house; she has supported it with seven pillars.

2.verse: She’s prepared a feast: She’s slaughtered her animals, poured a spiced wine, and set her table.

3.verse: She has sent out her servants with the invitation to come to the party; she, too, calls out from the highest point of the city:

4.verse: Lady Wisdom: Whoever is young and gullible, turn in here. You are welcome in this place! Then, turning to those who are naive, she says:

5.verse: Lady Wisdom: Come in. Come, eat my bread, and drink my spiced wine.

6.verse: Give up your gullible ways, your naive thoughts, for true life. Set your course for understanding.

7.verse: Whoever tries to discipline a scoffer should expect a hail of insults in return. Whoever tries to correct an evildoer is likely to get hurt in the process.

8.verse: So do not correct a scoffer unless you are ready to be hated, but correct the wise and you will be loved.

9.verse: Give instruction to the wise, and they will become wiser. Teach upstanding people, and they will learn even more.

10.verse: Reverence for the Eternal, the one True God, is the beginning of wisdom; true knowledge of the Holy One is the start of understanding.

11.verse: Lady Wisdom: Through me your days will be lengthened, and years will be added to your life.

12.verse: If you are wise, wisdom is its own reward. If you mock what you don’t understand, you alone will suffer the consequences.

13.verse: Compared to Wisdom, the Lady Folly is rowdy and loud, naive and ignorant.

14.verse: She sits by the door of her house, on a bench at the highest place in the city,

15.verse: Lady Wisdom has built a house, prepared a feast, and now invites the young, the simple, and the naive to come to her party. She wants her house full of guests and spilling over with life, yet hers is not the only invitation. There is competition in the streets. Another woman vies for the attention of the young and impressionable. She, too, wants her house full, but of deceit and seduction; and when it is, death and misery join the revelry. Wisdom addresses a broad audience. First, there are the wise who already know and worship the one True God, who do what is right in God’s eyes, and who experience the resulting benefits. They need only to be reminded about God’s ways. Second, there are the mockers and fools who reject God’s teaching and consistently do what is wrong in spite of its consequences. They need to be confronted and called to change their ways. Finally, there are the naive who straddle the fence, one day going this way, another day going that way. Wisdom extends herself to reach them, to point clearly toward the decision they have to make. Crooning to passersby who hurry straight on to their destinations:

16.verse: Lady Folly: Whoever is young and gullible, turn in here. You are welcome in this place! Then, she turns to the naive.

17.verse: Lady Folly: Stolen water tastes so much sweeter! Bread secreted away is much more satisfying to eat!

18.verse: But those who pause to listen to Lady Folly do not know death is the next stop, that her guests are walking cadavers.

1.verse: The proverbs of Solomon: A wise son makes his father glad, but a foolish one fills his mother with sorrow.

2.verse: Solomon’s proverbs were originally short, pithy, easily remembered sayings brought together around certain themes. They started as oral traditions and were eventually written in a Hebrew poetic form known as parallelism. Chapters 10–15 are dominated by antithetical parallelism, meaning a statement is made in line 1 and then contrasted in line 2. Chapters 16–22 contain both synonymous and synthetic parallelism. In synonymous parallelism, the ideas in line 1 are repeated in line 2 using different words. In synthetic parallelism, later lines serve to expand, define, and elaborate the first lines. Riches gained through dishonest means will eventually vanish, but doing what is right avoids a deadly consequence.

3.verse: The Eternal does not allow the right-living to go hungry, but He will frustrate the plans of the wicked.

4.verse: A slack hand produces nothing but poverty, but an industrious hand soon takes hold of riches.

5.verse: A wise son stores up for the winter months while it is still summer, but a shameful son lies around even during the harvest.

6.verse: Blessings come to those who do what is right, but words spoken by the wicked cover up violent schemes.

7.verse: The memory of one who lived with integrity brings joy, but the legacy of a wrongdoer will rot away.

8.verse: The wise at heart will gladly obey direction, but one who fills the air with meaningless talk will fall into ruin.

9.verse: The path of integrity is always safe, but a person who follows a crooked way will be exposed.

10.verse: Whoever winks his eye signals trouble, and whoever fills the air with meaningless talk will fall into ruin.

11.verse: The mouth of the righteous is a spring of life, but words spoken by the wicked cover up violent schemes.

12.verse: Hatred fuels dissension, but love calms all rebellions.

13.verse: Wisdom lives where insightful words are spoken, but harsh punishment awaits the senseless.

14.verse: The wise store up knowledge as a safeguard, but the meaningless chatter of fools means that chaos is near.

15.verse: The wealth of the rich is their powerful fortress; the poverty of the poor reduces them to rubble.

16.verse: The reward of those who do right is a satisfied life, but the profits gained by those who do wrong is used to sin.

17.verse: Those who accept instruction are travelers on the road to a meaningful life, but those who refuse correction wander off and pave a path to ruin.

18.verse: Lips that lie cover deep-seated hatred, and whoever spreads a libelous rumor is acting as a fool.

19.verse: The more you talk, the more likely you will cross the line and say the wrong thing; but if you are wise, you’ll speak less and with restraint.

20.verse: The speech of those who do right is of greater value than the finest silver, but the thoughts of wrongdoers are worthless.

21.verse: The right-living teach many, but fools die with no clue how to live well.

22.verse: Perhaps the ancients knew the power of words better than we do. Words can conceal, reveal, destroy, and encourage. Words are extremely powerful, so Wisdom urges us to use a few carefully chosen words and to pick our conversations equally well. The blessing of the Eternal is what makes someone rich, and He doesn’t add pain to it.

23.verse: Mischief is the sport of fools, but wise actions bring joy to a person with insight.

24.verse: Whatever wrongdoers fear the most will happen to them, but those who do right will receive what they long for.

25.verse: After the storm passes, the wrongdoers are blown away, but those who do right are safe and sound on their firm foundations forever.

26.verse: As vinegar vexes the teeth, and as smoke irritates the eyes, so a slacker annoys his boss.

27.verse: Reverence for the Eternal makes for a long and peaceful life, but a wrongdoer will have years taken away.

28.verse: The hope of those who do right is joy and celebration, but the only prospect for those who do wrong is futility.

29.verse: The way of the Eternal offers safety to those who love justice, but it destroys those who perpetrate evil.

30.verse: The right-living will never have their land taken away, but wrongdoers will be uprooted.

31.verse: Wisdom flows from the mouths of those who do right, but tongues that twist the truth will be cut out.

32.verse: The lips of the right-living understand what is proper, but the mouths of wrongdoers twist and pervert the truth.

1.verse: Dishonesty in business disgusts the Eternal, but fair dealing delights Him.

2.verse: Business may well be the most common human activity, so God cares deeply about how we conduct our business. Many proverbs address honesty in all forms of business—buying, selling, negotiating, transacting, and working. All of these depend on trust. Deceit in business causes many people to suffer. In fact, world economies and all our livelihoods depend in large measure on truthfulness, honesty, and fair dealings in the market. When pride comes, shame is not far behind, but wisdom accompanies those who are humble.

3.verse: The right-living are guided by integrity, but the crooked ways of the faithless will lead to ruin.

4.verse: Riches won’t matter on the day of wrath, but right living will rescue from death.

5.verse: The good deeds of the blameless pave a peaceful, productive path, but wrongdoers trip over their own faults.

6.verse: The good deeds of the upright will rescue them, but the faithless will be conquered by their shallow desires.

7.verse: When wrongdoers die, their hopes die with them. Their great expectations vanish into nothing more than a dream.

8.verse: Those who do right are pulled from trouble; it falls on wrongdoers instead who are left to sink in their own problems.

9.verse: The words of the godless ruin those close to them, but through insight the right-living are spared.

10.verse: When prosperity comes to those who do right, the whole city celebrates; but when the wicked get their just punishment, there is joyous cheering.

11.verse: A city thrives through the blessing of those living right, but the words of a wrongdoer will bring it to ruin.

12.verse: Whoever puts down another is not wise, but one who knows better keeps quiet.

13.verse: A gossip can’t keep anything confidential, but a reliable person protects a secret.

14.verse: Without wise guidance, a nation falls; but victory is certain when there are plenty of wise counselors.

15.verse: Trouble compounds when you guarantee a stranger’s debt, but you’ll be safe if you refuse the pledge.

16.verse: A gracious woman acquires honor, but cruel people are only interested in acquiring money.

17.verse: Kindness is its own reward, but cruelty is a self-inflicted wound.

18.verse: The wicked earn a living by deception, but the one who plants righteousness gathers a true harvest.

19.verse: Indeed, those who do what is right will live a good life, but those who pursue evil will die.

20.verse: The Eternal detests a crooked heart and a warped mind, but He takes great pleasure in those who follow the right way.

21.verse: Certainly those who do wrong will not escape punishment, but those who do right will go free.

22.verse: Much like a gold ring in the snout of a pig, so is a beautiful woman who lacks good judgment.

23.verse: Those who live right crave what is good, but the prospect of wrongdoers is wrath.

24.verse: One shares liberally and yet gains even more, while another hoards more than is right and still has need.

25.verse: A giving person will receive much in return, and someone who gives water will also receive the water he needs.

26.verse: Generosity places God’s gifts and blessings into circulation. The principle is simply stated: by giving we receive. This may seem counterintuitive, but it is how God’s economy works. As Jesus said, “Don’t hold back—give freely, and you’ll have plenty poured back into your lap—a good measure, pressed down, shaken together, brimming over. You’ll receive in the same measure you give” (Luke 6:38). Curses fall upon those who hoard food, but blessings come to those who sell food.

27.verse: Those who seek good find the goodwill of others, but those who look for evil are sure to find it.

28.verse: Those who trust in their wealth are headed for great disappointment, but those who do right will sprout like green leaves in the spring.

29.verse: A person who stirs up trouble in his family will inherit stormy winds, and foolish troublers will end up serving the wise.

30.verse: The tree of life grows where the fruit of right-living falls, and whoever wins souls is wise.

31.verse: If the righteous can expect to be repaid on earth, how much more can the ungodly and the sinners?

1.verse: Those who love discipline love knowledge, but fools hate any kind of correction.

2.verse: The Eternal prefers those who do good, but He condemns those who plot evil.

3.verse: Doing what is wrong keeps everyone off balance and insecure, but those who do right will never be uprooted.

4.verse: A dignified wife brings honor to her husband, but a shameful wife is like decay eating away at his bones.

5.verse: The thoughts of the right-living tend toward justice, but the guidance of the wicked is trickery and treachery.

6.verse: The words of the wicked ambush from the shadows, seeking blood, but the speech of the honest keeps them free.

7.verse: The wrongdoers are overthrown—no one is left! But the house of the right-living remains strong.

8.verse: A person is commended for expressing insight, but a perverted heart is despised.

9.verse: It is better to be overlooked and have a servant than to be pretentious and have nothing to eat.

10.verse: Those who are righteous treat their animals humanely, but the compassion of the wicked is really inhumane.

11.verse: A person in a positive relationship with God stands in a right relationship with His creation. How we treat animals may mirror our souls—not just the pets in our home, but the pets in our neighborhood and the animals in our food supply. One who is truly right with God considers the needs of His creatures. Whoever works the land will have more than enough food, but whoever follows empty pursuits lacks sense.

12.verse: The wicked envy what the evil plunder, but the root of the right-living produces fruit for all.

13.verse: A wrongdoer is soon boxed in by his deceitful talk, but the one who does right escapes from trouble unharmed.

14.verse: Words spoken wisely result in much good, and working with your hands pays a large reward.

15.verse: Fools follow their own directions and think they are right, but wise people listen intently to advice.

16.verse: A fool’s anger is quickly evident, but a clever person knows how to hide his flaws.

17.verse: A faithful witness speaks the truth, but a false witness utters lies.

18.verse: Thoughtless words cut deeply like a thrusting sword, but the speech of the wise is a healing balm.

19.verse: Truth spoken will stand forever, but lies survive only briefly.

20.verse: Deceit darkens the hearts of those who plot evil, but advocates of peace have joy.

21.verse: The right-living are not overcome with calamity, but wrongdoers have their fill of it.

22.verse: Lying lips disgust the Eternal, but those who act faithfully delight Him.

23.verse: A clever man is careful in revealing what he knows, but a fool betrays his incompetence.

24.verse: The hand of the hard workers will one day rule, and slackers will be forced to labor.

25.verse: The weight of worry drags us down, but a good word lightens our day.

26.verse: Those who live right are good guides to those who follow, but wrongdoers will steer their friends down the wrong path.

27.verse: Slackers don’t take time to cook their food, but hard workers prize everything they have.

28.verse: Life springs up along the path of integrity, and death has no place along its course.

1.verse: A wise child is attentive to his parents’ instruction, but the mocker is deaf to correction.

2.verse: A person eats well when he speaks wisely, but the treacherous crave violence.

3.verse: Those who guard their speech insure they will take another breath, but those who talk without thinking guarantee their demise.

4.verse: Slackers crave but have their fill of nothing, but the hardworking desire and are completely satisfied.

5.verse: The right-living will not tolerate any lie, but wrongdoers come to shame and embarrassment.

6.verse: Doing right keeps the innocent on the path of life, but doing wrong is the downfall of the wicked.

7.verse: One pretends he is wealthy but has nothing, while another seems to be poor but has great wealth.

8.verse: The rich are targeted and must ransom their lives, but no one bothers to threaten the poor.

9.verse: The light of the right-living brings joy as it burns brightly; the lamp of a wrongdoer will be snuffed out.

10.verse: Arrogance only produces arguments, but wisdom accompanies those well advised.

11.verse: Money earned hastily is easily lost, but hard-earned money continues to grow.

12.verse: Hope postponed grieves the heart; but when a dream comes true, life is full and sweet.

13.verse: The one who hates good counsel will reap failure and ruin, but the one who reveres God’s instruction will be rewarded.

14.verse: Wise instruction is a spring yielding a satisfied life; those who follow it avoid the traps that lead to death.

15.verse: Good sense brings blessing, but the road of the treacherous is long and rough.

16.verse: A clever person acquires knowledge and then acts on it; but a fool advertises his folly for all to see.

17.verse: An untrustworthy messenger stirs up trouble, but a faithful emissary is curative balm.

18.verse: A person who turns from correction faces poverty and shame, but one who regards constructive criticism is well respected.

19.verse: A dream fulfilled is the sweetness of life, but abandoning evil is repulsive to fools.

20.verse: One who walks with the wise becomes wise, but whoever keeps company with fools only hurts himself.

21.verse: Trouble eagerly pursues the sinner, but success rewards the right-living.

22.verse: A good person leaves an inheritance for his grandchildren, but the wealth of the sinner is eventually passed on to the right-living.

23.verse: Though the fields of the poor yield a bumper crop in a land without justice, it is stolen out from under them.

24.verse: Those who spare the rod of discipline hate their children, but those who are quick to correct them show true love.

25.verse: Those who do right have plenty to eat, while those who do wrong go hungry.

1.verse: A wise woman builds her house, but a foolish one picks it to splinters with her own hands.

2.verse: Whoever travels through life with integrity respects the Eternal, but whoever turns from it hates Him.

3.verse: A fool’s words betray his pride and invite punishment, but the humble speech of the wise will spare them.

4.verse: A farm without oxen has a manger without grain; there’s a good return in the strength of an ox.

5.verse: An honest witness can always be trusted, but a false witness breathes out nothing but lies.

6.verse: Wisdom eludes mockers, though they seek it, but insight comes quickly to those with understanding.

7.verse: Walk away from the company of fools, for you cannot find insight in their words.

8.verse: It takes wisdom for the clever to understand the path they are on, but the fool is deceived by his own foolishness.

9.verse: Fools make a mockery of guilt and repentance, but those who do what is right receive special standing.

10.verse: Only the heart can know its own resentment; likewise no stranger can experience its joy.

11.verse: The house of the wicked will be destroyed, while the tent of the upright will prosper.

12.verse: Before every person lies a road that seems to be right, but the end of that road is death and destruction.

13.verse: Laughter can mask heartache, and joy often gives way to grief.

14.verse: A disloyal heart has its fill of disloyal ways, but a good person will be satisfied from above.

15.verse: The gullible believe anything they are told, but clever people know to question every step.

16.verse: The wise are cautious and stay far from evil, but fools are hotheaded and careless.

17.verse: Quick-tempered people make fools of themselves, and evil schemers make many enemies.

18.verse: The naive are heirs to foolishness, but the clever are honored with insight.

19.verse: Evil people will be humbled before the good; the wicked will stoop at the doorstep of the righteous.

20.verse: The poor are hated even by their own neighbors, but the rich are loved by many friends.

21.verse: Those who have contempt for their neighbors are sinners, but those who are kind to the poor are happy.

22.verse: Don’t those who work evil stray from the truth? Those who plan goodness experience unfailing love and faithfulness.

23.verse: Prosperity comes from hard work, but talking too much leads to great scarcity.

24.verse: The wise are honored for their wealth; the reward of fools is more foolishness.

25.verse: A truthful witness protects lives by not allowing evil to triumph, but a deceitful witness speaks lies and puts the innocent in jeopardy.

26.verse: Reverence for the Eternal brings bold confidence, and one’s offspring will have hope of protection.

27.verse: Respect and honor for Him is the basis of a satisfied life, which guards a person from being trapped in the snares of death.

28.verse: A king’s splendor is in his many people, but a declining population will lead to his ruin.

29.verse: Whoever is patient and slow to anger shows great understanding, but whoever has a quick temper magnifies his foolishness.

30.verse: A serene heart can add years to one’s life; but jealous passion rots the bones.

31.verse: The wrong kind of passion can be a dangerous thing. Too often people are ruled by strong emotions, thoughts that cannot be checked, and actions that cannot be controlled. If that’s the case, then you are putting your life and well-being in jeopardy. Peace of mind, tranquility of soul, and serenity of heart become the recipe for a long, happy life. Whoever oppresses the poor insults his Maker, but anyone who is gracious to the needy honors Him.

32.verse: The wicked are waylaid by their evil actions, but the right-living find hope’s sanctuary even in their death.

33.verse: Wisdom rests in the heart of one with insight and can even be experienced by fools.

34.verse: Living according to God’s instructions makes a nation great, but sin colors those who commit it with disgrace.

35.verse: The king shows kindness to a servant who acts wisely, but his anger burns toward one who brings shame.

1.verse: A tender answer turns away rage, but a prickly reply spikes anger.

2.verse: The words of the wise extend knowledge, but foolish people utter nonsense.

3.verse: The Eternal can see all things; His gaze is fixed on both the evil and the good.

4.verse: A word of encouragement heals the one who receives it, but a deceitful word breaks the spirit.

5.verse: Fools refuse their parents’ guidance, but sensible children accept correction.

6.verse: Great treasure may be found where the right-living make their home, but trouble awaits the wicked at every turn.

7.verse: When the wise speak, knowledge spreads far and wide, but fools care nothing about such matters.

8.verse: When the wicked offer sacrifices, they disgust the Eternal, but the prayers of those who do right are a pleasure to Him.

9.verse: The lifestyle of the wicked is repulsive to Him, while those who do right delight Him.

10.verse: Harsh punishment is waiting for those who reject the path of life, and those who hate correction will die.

11.verse: The grave and destruction are fully exposed before the Eternal; how much more does He know the thoughts of Adam’s children!

12.verse: Those who mock others don’t like being corrected, so they keep their distance from the wise.

13.verse: A warm, smiling face reveals a joy-filled heart, but heartache crushes the spirit and darkens the appearance.

14.verse: Those who have understanding hearts hunger after knowledge, but those with no understanding feast on foolishness.

15.verse: The poor and oppressed suffer hardship day after day, but those with kind hearts continually feast.

16.verse: It is better to live with less and honor the Eternal than to have riches and carry the burdens that come with them.

17.verse: Better to eat only vegetables served lovingly than a fattened ox served hatefully.

18.verse: A hot-headed person stirs up trouble, but one with patience settles a fight.

19.verse: Lazy people walk a path overgrown with thornbushes, but those with integrity travel a wide, level road.

20.verse: A wise child makes his father happy, but a foolish man despises his mother.

21.verse: Foolishness brings sheer joy to those who have no sense, but people with insight steer a straight course through life.

22.verse: Plans fall apart without proper advice; but with the right guidance, they come together nicely.

23.verse: There is great joy in having the right answer, and how sweet is the right word at the right time!

24.verse: For the wise the road of life climbs up steep grades in order to avoid the slide down to the grave.

25.verse: The Eternal splinters the house of the haughty, but He secures the property of widows.

26.verse: It is ironic that we may have more to fear from the proud and powerful than from the poor and needy. Those who have want more, and so they take it. Oh, maybe they won’t pick your pocket or break into your home. Their ways are more subtle and more effective. As James, Jesus’ brother, wrote, “Isn’t it the rich who step on you while climbing the ladder of success? And isn’t it the rich who take advantage of you and drag you into court?” (James 2:6b). James isn’t describing all the rich, of course, but many have made their fortunes off the backs of others. God is the One who can protect the poor, the One who can reduce the grand houses of the haughty to splinters. The thoughts of the wrongdoers repulse the Eternal, but kind words are pure pleasure for Him.

27.verse: Those who take illegal gains injure their families, but those who refuse a bribe will live in peace.

28.verse: The right-living think before they speak, but wrongdoers simply spew evil.

29.verse: The Eternal stays far from the wrongdoers, but He listens to the prayer of the right-living.

30.verse: Bright eyes and a cheerful expression bring joy to the heart, and good news revives the spirit and renews health.

31.verse: Those who learn from the lessons of life will join the others who are wise.

32.verse: Those who disregard discipline sabotage themselves, but those who are open to correction gain understanding.

33.verse: Reverence for the Eternal is the first lesson of wisdom, and humility always precedes honor.

1.verse: People go about making their plans, but the Eternal has the final word.

2.verse: Even when you think you have good intentions, He knows your real motives.

3.verse: Whatever you do, do it as service to Him, and He will guarantee your success.

4.verse: The Eternal made everything for a reason. Even wrongdoers fit in His plans; troubled times await them.

5.verse: He abhors arrogant people. Make no mistake about it! They will be punished!

6.verse: The penalty of sin is removed by love and loyalty; and by devotion to the Eternal, evil is avoided.

7.verse: When people make good choices, He is pleased; He even causes their enemies to live peacefully near them.

8.verse: Better to have little and stand for what is right than to become rich by doing what is wrong.

9.verse: People do their best making plans for their lives, but the Eternal guides each step.

10.verse: The king makes a decision under divine inspiration, but he must never render an unfair judgment.

11.verse: The Eternal requires that business be conducted honestly; He wants fairness in all your dealings.

12.verse: When kings commit evil, it is despicable, because their thrones should be built on justice.

13.verse: Kings admire those who tell the truth; they adore those who set the record straight.

14.verse: A king’s rage signals that people will die, but whoever is wise will pacify him.

15.verse: If a king is smiling brightly, life will be granted; his favor is like a cloud swelled with the first spring rain.

16.verse: How much better it is to receive wisdom than the riches of gold and to gain understanding over some silver prize!

17.verse: The highway of the just bypasses evil; those who watch where they’re going protect their lives from sin.

18.verse: Pride precedes destruction; an arrogant spirit gives way to a nasty fall.

19.verse: It is better to be humble and live among the poor, than to divide up stolen property with the proud.

20.verse: Those devoted to instruction will prosper in goodness; those who trust in the Eternal will experience His favor.

21.verse: The wise at heart have a reputation for understanding; pleasant words make the lips more persuasive.

22.verse: Understanding for those who have it is a spring of life, but it is pointless to try and instruct a fool.

23.verse: From a wise heart flow careful words; wise words make the lips more persuasive.

24.verse: Pleasant words are like a honeycomb: they drip sweet food for life and bring health to the body.

25.verse: Before every person lies a road that seems to be right, but at the end of that road death and destruction wait.

26.verse: People work to stay alive, pressed daily by their need to eat.

27.verse: Good-for-nothings conjure up evil ideas; their conversations fuel destructive fires.

28.verse: Perverse people stir up contention; gossip makes best friends into enemies.

29.verse: Violent people try to recruit their neighbors, wanting to lead them down the vile path of evil they have chosen.

30.verse: Body language can expose a person’s intentions: whoever winks the eye is planning perversity; whoever purses his lips is intent on evil.

31.verse: Gray hair is a crown of honor, earned by living the right kind of life.

32.verse: It is better to be a patient man than a mighty warrior, better to be someone who controls his temper than someone who conquers a city.

33.verse: We may try to control the roll of the dice, but actually, the Eternal decides what they will determine.

1.verse: Better to gnaw on a bit of dry crust in peace than to feast in a house full of stress.

2.verse: A wise servant will be put in charge of a child who behaves badly and will take a share of the inheritance like one of the family.

3.verse: Silver is purified in the crucible, gold in the furnace, but motives of the heart are judged by the Eternal.

4.verse: Wrongdoers perk up when listening to gossip, and liars lean in close to hear talk of mischief.

5.verse: Anyone who makes fun of the poor disparages his Maker, and those who celebrate another’s misfortune will not escape certain punishment.

6.verse: Grandchildren are the crowning glory and ultimate delight of old age, and parents are the pride of their children.

7.verse: Elegant speech sounds odd when it comes from a fool, and a lie on the lips of a leader is even more out of place!

8.verse: A bribe is like an enchanting charm to one who counts on it— everywhere he looks he sees the illusion of success.

9.verse: Those who forgive faults foster love, but those who repeatedly recall them ruin relationships.

10.verse: A single correction makes a more lasting impression on one who is wise than a hundred lashes do on a fool.

11.verse: Evil people are determined to rebel, and so a merciless messenger will chase them down.

12.verse: Better to face a mother bear stripped of her cubs than to encounter a fool caught up in his foolishness.

13.verse: Those who repay good with evil bring unrelenting trouble upon their families.

14.verse: Picking a fight is like leaking water from a crack in a dam, so walk away from an argument before the outburst.

15.verse: Both of these deeply offend the Eternal: one who acquits the guilty and one who condemns the innocent.

16.verse: Even if fools had the means to obtain wisdom, they would not be able to benefit from it.

17.verse: A true friend loves regardless of the situation, and a real brother exists to share the tough times.

18.verse: Only a fool shakes hands on a deal and guarantees repayment of someone else’s loan.

19.verse: A person who loves sin loves a fight, and one who builds a grand entrance dares others to tear it down.

20.verse: Crooked-hearted people never recognize anything good, and those who distort the truth court disaster.

21.verse: Having a fool for a child is misery; there is no joy in parenting a fool.

22.verse: A joy-filled heart is curative balm, but a broken spirit hurts all the way to the bone.

23.verse: A wicked person accepts a bribe under the table to derail the course of justice.

24.verse: Those who understand look to wisdom for guidance, but fools fasten their eyes on some distant horizon.

25.verse: Foolish children irritate their fathers and embitter their mothers.

26.verse: Also know this: It is wrong to penalize those who do what is right or to lash the noble because of their integrity.

27.verse: Those with knowledge know when to be quiet, and those with understanding know how to remain calm.

28.verse: Even a fool who keeps quiet is considered wise, for when he keeps his mouth shut, he appears clever.

1.verse: Whoever pulls away from others to focus solely on his own desires disregards any sense of sound judgment.

2.verse: A fool never delights in true knowledge but only wants to express what’s on his mind.

3.verse: When wrongdoers arrive, disgrace is right there with them, for shame is the companion of dishonor.

4.verse: Words bubble up from waters deep within a person; a stream gushes from the fountain of wisdom.

5.verse: It is wrong for a judge to show partiality to the guilty or to rob the innocent of justice.

6.verse: When a fool’s lips move, a fight breaks out; it’s as if his mouth is begging for a beating.

7.verse: The mouths of fools are their destruction, and their lips entrap their very souls.

8.verse: Whispered gossip is like a delicious first course: it is devoured with pleasure and penetrates deeply.

9.verse: Those who slack off at work are no different from vandals.

10.verse: The Eternal is known to be like a sturdy watchtower; those who do right flee to Him for protection.

11.verse: The rich think their wealth is their sturdy fortress; they imagine it to be an invincible wall of security.

12.verse: A proud heart precedes destruction, and before honor is humility.

13.verse: To respond to a matter before you hear about it shows foolishness and brings shame.

14.verse: The human spirit can endure a long illness, but who can survive a crushed spirit?

15.verse: Clever people go after knowledge to obtain it, and wise people attune their ears to hear it.

16.verse: The right gift at the right time can open up new opportunities and gains access to influential people.

17.verse: The first ones to tell their side of a story seem right until cross-examined by their peers.

18.verse: Casting lots can settle conflicts and decide between powerful opponents.

19.verse: Winning over an offended brother is harder than breaching a strong city’s defenses; such fights are as tough as the iron gates of a castle.

20.verse: Good words satisfy like a fine meal; yes, good conversations are sure to satisfy.

21.verse: Words have power in matters of life and death, and those who love them will savor their fruit.

22.verse: The man who finds a wife finds something good, and the favor of the Eternal is indeed his.

23.verse: The poor plead for help, but the rich respond harshly.

24.verse: Someone with many so-called friends may end up friendless, but a true friend is closer than a brother.

1.verse: Better to be poor and live with integrity than a fool with a foul mouth.

2.verse: Surely there’s no advantage for a person without knowledge, and whoever moves too quickly misses the turn.

3.verse: Foolishness diverts the course of life, yet the heart rebels against the Eternal.

4.verse: Wealth attracts many friends, but the poor are soon separated from theirs.

5.verse: A false witness will not escape punishment, and one who breathes lies will not go free.

6.verse: Many try to win the favor of a generous person, and everyone is a friend to someone who gives gifts.

7.verse: If a poor man is hated by his relatives, it is even more likely his friends will avoid him too! Anyone who is calling after them [is not to be found].

8.verse: Whoever gains a wise heart loves his own soul, and whoever preserves understanding experiences true goodness.

9.verse: A false witness will not escape punishment, and whoever breathes lies will not survive.

10.verse: Something is wrong when a fool lives a pampered life, but it is much worse when a slave takes charge of princes.

11.verse: A person with discretion is not easily angered; he gains respect by overlooking an offense.

12.verse: A king’s rage is like the thunderous roar of a lion, but his favor is like a cooling mist upon the grass.

13.verse: Foolish children bring misery to their fathers, and a wife’s bickering is a constant dripping as from a leaky roof.

14.verse: Houses and riches may be inherited from parents, but a sensible wife is a gift from the Eternal.

15.verse: Laziness lulls people into a deep sleep; a slacker will have nothing to eat.

16.verse: Whoever keeps God’s commands lengthens his life, but a careless lifestyle ends in death.

17.verse: Whoever cares for the poor makes a loan to the Eternal; such kindness will be repaid in full and with interest.

18.verse: Discipline your children while there is still hope of influencing their future, so as not to play a part in their destruction.

19.verse: A hot-tempered man will pay a penalty; if you bail him out, it will not be the last time; the cycle will repeat.

20.verse: Heed counsel, act on instruction, and you will become wise later in life.

21.verse: The impulses of the human heart may run wild, but the Eternal’s plan will prevail.

22.verse: Loyalty is a trait admired in others, and being destitute is better than being a liar.

23.verse: Reverence for the Eternal leads to a fulfilled life; those who have it will sleep well, for disaster will not touch them.

24.verse: Some people are so lazy—they reach for food on the plate but lack the will to bring it up to their mouths.

25.verse: If you beat one who mocks, the naive will see and learn a lesson; if you correct someone with understanding, that’s all he needs to grow a little wiser.

26.verse: Children who mistreat their father and run down their mother are a root of shame and disgrace.

27.verse: My child, should you stop listening to instruction, you will wander from the voice of knowledge.

28.verse: A worthless witness ridicules justice, and the mouth of the wrongdoer savors every morsel of trouble.

29.verse: Severe penalties are prepared for those who mock, and fools expect their backs to be flogged.

1.verse: Too much wine begins to mock you, too much strong drink leads to noisy fights, and whoever is misled by either is not wise.

2.verse: A king’s wrath strikes fear like a lion’s roar; those who provoke him to anger sentence themselves to death.

3.verse: Honor is due those who refuse to fight at the drop of a hat, but every fool jumps at an opportunity to quarrel.

4.verse: A slacker procrastinates when it is time to plow; so when it’s time for harvest, there are no crops in the field.

5.verse: The real motives come from deep within a person—as from deep waters— but a discerning person is able to draw them up and expose them.

6.verse: Most people claim to be loyal, but can anyone find a trustworthy person?

7.verse: The right-living act with integrity; the children who follow their example are happy.

8.verse: When a king sits on his throne as judge, he ferrets out all evil and scatters it with his royal stare.

9.verse: Who can say, “I have cleaned my heart”? or who can proclaim, “I am purified from sin”?

10.verse: False weights and differing measures are alike: both are disgusting to the Eternal.

11.verse: Youth reveal their true natures by their actions whether they do what is pure and right or not.

12.verse: Ears to listen, eyes to see— the Eternal designed them both.

13.verse: Do not fall in love with sleep, or you will awake a poor person. Stay awake, get to work, and you will have more than enough food.

14.verse: “Bad quality for a bad price,” bargains the buyer; but then he runs off with his prize in tow, bragging, “What a steal!”

15.verse: Gold and rubies abound, but lips that utter knowledge are a rare jewel.

16.verse: If someone guarantees a stranger’s debt, hold his garment as collateral; if that stranger is a foreigner, hold the creditor responsible.

17.verse: At first the bread of lies tastes sweet until guilt reduces it to gravel in the mouth.

18.verse: Plans are finalized on the basis of good counsel, so only go to war when you have wise instructions.

19.verse: A gossip will reveal your secrets! So avoid the company of people who talk openly and foolishly.

20.verse: If someone pronounces a curse on his parents, the lamp of his life will be snuffed out as complete darkness creeps in.

21.verse: An inheritance acquired hastily at first will end up not being blessed after all.

22.verse: Do not say, “I will get even for this evil.” Wait for the Eternal; He will defend you.

23.verse: He despises dishonesty in business; false weights and deceptive scales are wrong.

24.verse: Every one of our steps is directed by Him; so how can we attempt to figure out our own way?

25.verse: Those who rashly dedicate something to God are trapped; only afterward do they realize what they’ve promised.

26.verse: A wise king weeds out the wrongdoers, then drives over them with his threshing wheel of justice.

27.verse: The lamp of the Eternal illuminates the human spirit, searching our most intimate thoughts.

28.verse: Loyal love and faithfulness safeguard the king; his throne is perpetuated through loyal love.

29.verse: The best asset of youth is the strength of the body, but the beauty of age is gray hair.

30.verse: Severe punishment scrubs away evil, and tough blows scour the innermost parts.

1.verse: The king’s heart is like a channel of water directed by the Eternal: He chooses which way He bends it.

2.verse: Everyone may think his own way of living is right, but the Eternal examines our hearts.

3.verse: To do what is right and to seek justice— these please Him more than sacrifice.

4.verse: The lamp of the wicked lights his way; a proud look, an arrogant heart—all sin.

5.verse: A well-thought-out plan will work to your advantage, but hasty actions will cost you dearly.

6.verse: The fortune made by a swindler is a fast-burning fog and a recipe for death.

7.verse: Wicked people will be swept up in their own violence because they refuse to seek justice.

8.verse: Dishonest people walk along the crooked path they have made, but the innocent travel the straight course they have laid.

9.verse: It is better to dwell outside on the corner of your roof than to live inside your house with a badgering wife.

10.verse: Wicked people delight in doing bad things; their neighbors never see even a hint of compassion.

11.verse: A naive person wises up when he sees a mocker punished. A wise person becomes even wiser just by being instructed.

12.verse: The right-living understands how evildoers operate; he subverts them and ruins their plans.

13.verse: If you ignore the groans of the poor, one day your own cries for help will go unanswered.

14.verse: A gift given in secret soothes anger, and a present offered privately calms fierce rage.

15.verse: When justice is done, those who are in the right celebrate, but those who make trouble are terrified.

16.verse: People who wander from the way of wise living will lie down in the company of corpses.

17.verse: Those who live to party, who pursue pleasure, will end up penniless; those who enjoy lots of wine and rich food will never have money.

18.verse: The wicked become a ransom for those who live right, and the faithless pay the penalty for their treachery against the upright.

19.verse: You would be better off living in the middle of the desert than with an angry and argumentative wife.

20.verse: The wise have a generous supply of fine food and oil in their homes, but fools are wasteful, consuming every last drop.

21.verse: Whoever pursues justice and treats others with kindness discovers true life marked by integrity and respect.

22.verse: One wise person can rise against a city of mighty men and cause the citadel they trust to collapse.

23.verse: Guard your words, mind what you say, and you will keep yourself out of trouble.

24.verse: The name “mocker” applies to one who is proud and pompous because he is defiantly arrogant.

25.verse: What slackers crave will surely kill them because they refuse to work.

26.verse: All day, every day the greedy want more, while those who live right give generously.

27.verse: The offerings of wrongdoers are despicable to God; it’s even worse when they bring them with evil motives.

28.verse: The testimony of a false witness is eventually impeached, but the person who truly listens will have the last word.

29.verse: The wicked wears a defiant face, but the right-living plans his path.

30.verse: No one is wise enough or smart enough, and no plan is good enough to stand up to the Eternal.

31.verse: No matter how well you arm for battle, victory is determined by Him.

1.verse: We do not like or want to believe it, but there are limits to what humans can accomplish. Whatever wisdom and knowledge we think we possess is nothing compared to God’s. Whatever plans we make will come to nothing unless they line up with God’s plans and purposes for us. A good reputation is preferable to riches, and the approval of others is better than precious silver or gold.

2.verse: Rich and poor have something in common: both are created by the Eternal.

3.verse: Prudent people see trouble coming and hide, but the naive walk right into it and take a beating.

4.verse: A humble person who fears the Eternal can expect to receive wealth, honor, and life.

5.verse: Thorny branches and traps lie ahead for those who follow perverse paths; those who want to preserve themselves will steer clear of them.

6.verse: Teach a child how to follow the right way; even when he is old, he will stay on course.

7.verse: The rich lord it over the poor, and the borrower is the slave to the lender.

8.verse: Those who sow injustice reap disaster, and their methods of oppression will fail.

9.verse: Generous people are genuinely blessed because they share their food with the poor.

10.verse: Expel a mocker, and watch the wrangling go with him; rivalry and rude remarks will also stop.

11.verse: Those who love a pure heart and speak with grace will find that the king is their friend.

12.verse: The Eternal keeps a watchful eye on those with knowledge, but He subverts the words of the faithless.

13.verse: A lazy person says, “A lion! Right outside! I will surely die in the streets! Yet another good reason to stay in today.”

14.verse: The alluring words of a seductive woman are a deep hole; the Eternal is incensed toward those who fall in.

15.verse: Foolishness consumes the heart of a child, but corporal punishment, properly administered, drives it far away.

16.verse: If you take advantage of the poor or coddle the rich to get ahead, you will end up destitute.

17.verse: The Words of the Wise Lend an ear, listen to these words of the wise, and align your thoughts with my instructions

18.verse: Because true pleasure will be yours by learning them, living them, and being ready to repeat them to others.

19.verse: In order that you will trust only in the Eternal, I teach them to you this day—yes, even you!

20.verse: In fact, didn’t I already write down for you Thirty axioms of good advice and sound knowledge

21.verse: To reveal to you what is reliably true so you can answer those who sent you with these truths you’ve learned?
