22.verse: Do not cheat poor people just because they are vulnerable or use shady tactics in court to crush those already suffering;

23.verse: For the Eternal is ready to take their case, and He ruins anyone who is out to ruin them.

24.verse: Do not befriend someone given to anger or hang around with a hothead.

25.verse: Odds are, you’ll learn his ways, become angry as well, and get caught in a trap.

26.verse: Do not be a person to guarantee someone else’s loan or put up collateral for the debts of an acquaintance;

27.verse: For if you do and you can’t repay, won’t you risk having your bed ripped out from under you?

28.verse: Do not steal property from your neighbors by moving the boundary markers your ancestors established.

29.verse: And as for those who are skilled in their work, they will be recognized and invited to serve kings rather than regular folk.

1.verse: When sitting down to eat with a ruler, take a moment to think about who you are with and what you are doing.

2.verse: If you are the type who eats too much too fast, do whatever is necessary to curb your enthusiasm for food.

3.verse: Also, do not eye the ruler’s delicacies, for the food may not be what it seems.

4.verse: Do not overwork yourself just to become wealthy; have enough sense to know when to quit.

5.verse: As soon as you become fixed on riches, they vanish. For suddenly they sprout wings and become like a soaring eagle flying high in the sky.

6.verse: Do not sit down and eat the bread of a tight-fisted fellow or desire any of his delicacies,

7.verse: For deep down he’s keeping track of the cost. He may say, “Eat up! Drink your fill!” but he does not mean a word of it.

8.verse: You’ll be sick and lose what little you did eat, and you’ll waste your breath carrying on a pleasant conversation.

9.verse: Do not waste your wisdom on a fool, for he doesn’t care for anything you have to say.

10.verse: Do not shift the property line by moving the boundary markers your ancestors established or try to steal property from orphans

11.verse: Because their Redeemer is strong, and He will plead their case against you.

12.verse: Develop a disciplined life. Be attentive so you can be well informed.

13.verse: Do not withhold discipline from children, since corporal punishment will not kill them.

14.verse: In fact, it may be that kind of punishment that will save them from an early grave.

15.verse: My son, if you live wisely, then my life will be fulfilled.

16.verse: My very soul will jump for joy when you speak what is true and right.

17.verse: Don’t be envious of those wrapped up in sin, but always maintain a healthy respect for the Eternal.

18.verse: Your future with Him will be certain, and you will not have hoped in vain.

19.verse: Listen, my son, be wise, and steer your life on the right course.

20.verse: Do not spend time with heavy wine drinkers or those who gorge themselves on meat.

21.verse: For both the drunk and the glutton will end up broke, sleeping life away, and clothed in rags.

22.verse: Pay attention to your father—after all, he gave you life— and don’t ignore your mother in her old age.

23.verse: Invest in truth, sock it away! Never cash in wisdom, guidance, or insight.

24.verse: The parents of the right-living will celebrate; yes, parents of children who make wise choices are happy.

25.verse: So make your parents happy; delight your mother—after all, she brought you into this world.

26.verse: My son, devote yourself to me fully. Observe my ways, and follow my directions:

27.verse: Being drawn to a prostitute is like falling down into a deep well, and being involved with a wicked woman is like descending into a narrow well. You may never get out alive.

28.verse: She waits for you, ready to ambush you like a thief and ready to multiply unfaithfulness among men.

29.verse: Who is wallowing in anguish? Who is full of sorrow? Who has conflicts? Who has complaints? Who has bruises and can’t remember where they came from? Who has bloodshot eyes?

30.verse: You know who: those who stay up late finishing off the wine, those who can’t stop savoring spiced wines.

31.verse: Look away from the enticing beauty of wine, the deep red hue; ignore how it shimmers in the cup and glides down your throat.

32.verse: Eventually, when you least expect it, it strikes like a snake; it stings like viper venom.

33.verse: Your vision will blur, and you’ll imagine strange things; you will say crazy, hurtful things and regret it later.

34.verse: You will reel and stagger as if caught on a wave of seasickness, as a sailor who holds on to a mast for dear life.

35.verse: You will say, “They slapped me, but it didn’t hurt. They beat me, and I didn’t feel a thing! Whenever I wake up from this stupor, I’ll have another drink!”

1.verse: The abuse of alcohol is as ancient as the first batch of Egyptian beer or the first sip of Noah’s wine (Genesis 9:20–21). Its wide availability today has made for binge drinking on college campuses, underage drinking by young teens, drunk driving on city streets, and alcoholic rants and abuse in the home. The sage offers a tragic description of a young man who goes from drink to drink and cannot get his bearings in life. Too many people lose so much life in an alcoholic stupor. Do not envy evil people or seek their friendship;

2.verse: For they are conniving and violent, and all they talk about is causing trouble.

3.verse: Wisdom is required to build a house; understanding is necessary to make it secure.

4.verse: Knowledge is needed to furnish all the rooms and fill them with beautiful treasures.

5.verse: A wise man possesses great strength, and an intelligent man knows how to increase it;

6.verse: For with wise guidance, you can wage a successful war, and with a council of many advisors, you will be victorious!

7.verse: Fools can’t grab hold of wisdom; it’s out of their reach; they dare not open their mouths in public for no one would listen anyway.

8.verse: Whoever schemes to carry out evil will be labeled a troublemaker.

9.verse: Such foolish plans are sinful, and the mocker is deplored by all.

10.verse: If you fall apart during a crisis, then you weren’t very strong to begin with.

11.verse: Rescue everyone you can of those being taken away and killed, and hold on to those innocent souls staggering toward their own slaughter.

12.verse: If you excuse yourself, saying, “Look, we didn’t know anything about this,” doesn’t God, who knows what you are really thinking, understand your motives? Isn’t your Protector aware of why you aren’t protecting the innocent? Will He not repay you in kind?

13.verse: Our world is all too familiar with violence and its victims. It’s easy to look the other way, pretend we didn’t see it, hope it goes away, or live in denial. Perhaps we are numbed to real violence because we are so entertained by the onslaught of it in modern media. But the violence in our homes, across our cities, and throughout the world is very real. Every day someone is beaten, captured, raped, enslaved, shot, robbed, stabbed, or run over. Wisdom calls us to step into those places and help those marching off to their deaths. God knows what we know. He knows what is in our hearts. My son, eat honey—it’s good for you; the honey that drips from the comb is sweet in your mouth.

14.verse: Know, too, that wisdom is good for your soul: if you find it, your reward will be a bright future and an enduring hope!

15.verse: Do not lurk outside the home of the just like a common criminal; do not tear up the place where he rests.

16.verse: For a good man may fall seven times and get back up again, but the wicked will stumble around and fall into misfortune.

17.verse: Do not celebrate when your enemies fall, and do not rejoice when they trip up;

18.verse: Or else the Eternal will know and be upset with you, and He will release them from His anger.

19.verse: Do not worry when evildoers go unpunished or be jealous when the wicked seem to prosper.

20.verse: Evil people will have no future; the life of the wicked will be snuffed out like a candle.

21.verse: My son, fear both the Eternal and His anointed ruler. It is not wise to associate with those rebelling against them

22.verse: Because disaster can arise from either of them without warning, and who knows what destruction comes down from both of them?

23.verse: The wise also say, It is not good for a judge to be partial.

24.verse: When a judge says to the guilty, “You are innocent,” he will be cursed by all people; he will be hated by nations.

25.verse: But those who reprimand evildoers will be celebrated, and good fortune will come their way.

26.verse: A straight answer is as precious as a kiss on the lips.

27.verse: Complete your work outside, and get your fields ready for next season; after that’s done, build your house.

28.verse: Do not testify against your neighbor without a reason; do not give misleading testimony.

29.verse: Do not say, “I’ll do to him what he did to me! I’ll repay him for what he did!”

30.verse: Once I passed by the property of a slacker, by the vineyard of a foolish man.

31.verse: You should have seen it! The entire field was overgrown with thorns. Every inch was covered with weeds. Even the stone wall was crumbling down.

32.verse: I took a moment to take it all in. The scene taught me:

33.verse: “A little sleep, a little rest, a few more minutes, a nice little nap.”

34.verse: But soon poverty will be on top of you like a robber, need will strike you down like a well-armed warrior.

1.verse: These words, too, are proverbs of King Solomon, words which Hezekiah, king of Judah, later told his scribes to record for posterity:

2.verse: God’s glory is shown when He conceals things; a king’s glory is shown in his ability to explore the facts of the matter.

3.verse: As the heights of heaven and the depths of earth are beyond comprehension, so are the hearts of kings.

4.verse: Take away the impurities from the silver, and a good smith can create something of value;

5.verse: Take away the wicked from among the king’s advisors, and his reign will be established with integrity.

6.verse: Do not claim to be important in the presence of the king or vie for a position within the company of great men.

7.verse: Truly, it is far sweeter to have someone of influence say to you, “Come up here and join us,” than to be ordered to some lower rank in front of a noble. Just because you think you have seen something

8.verse: doesn’t mean you should be quick to go to court, For what will you do when your neighbor disproves the charge and embarrasses you?

9.verse: Instead, discuss the matter directly with your neighbor, but in doing so, remember never to reveal another person’s secrets;

10.verse: For if you do, someone who hears you could disgrace you, and a bad reputation will cling to you ever afterward.

11.verse: A well-spoken word at just the right moment is like golden apples in settings of silver.

12.verse: To an attentive ear, constructive criticism from a truly wise person is like an earring or jewelry made of fine gold.

13.verse: Like a cooling snow that breaks the heat of a harvest day, so is the messenger who is faithful to those who sent him, for he refreshes the soul of his masters.

14.verse: Like clouds and wind that bring no rain, so is one who boasts of gifts promised but never delivered.

15.verse: Patience can soften up a leader, and a tender tongue can break even bone.

16.verse: When you find honey, remember to eat only what you need, because if you eat in excess, you may be sick and lose all of it.

17.verse: Don’t visit your neighbor too often, or he will become tired of you and grow to hate you.

18.verse: Like a maul and a sword and a sharp arrow all in one, so is anyone who bears false witness against a neighbor.

19.verse: Like a tooth that is rotten or a foot that is unsteady, so is relying on a person who can’t be trusted in times of trouble.

20.verse: Like a man who undresses in winter or a woman who pours vinegar on a wound, So is anyone who tries to sing happy songs to a sorrowful heart.

21.verse: If your enemy is hungry, give him something to eat; if he is thirsty, give him something to drink,

22.verse: For your kind treatment will be like heaping hot coals on his head, it may cause a change in heart, and the Eternal will repay you.

23.verse: Acts of kindness, especially when we know they are undeserved, awaken a slumbering conscience, stimulate sorrow, and perhaps even effect a change. They are the best ways to turn an enemy into a friend. As surely as a north wind drives the rain before it, a backbiting tongue brings angry looks.

24.verse: It is better to dwell outside on the corner of your roof than to live inside your house with a badgering wife.

25.verse: Like cool water to a weary soul, so is good news from a distant country.

26.verse: Like a muddy spring or a polluted fountain, so is a righteous person who gives in to the wicked.

27.verse: Eating too much honey is not good for you, nor is it good to seek one honor after another.

28.verse: Like a conquered city with no walls, so is a man who has no self-control.

1.verse: Like snow in the summer and rain in the time of harvest, so honor is never fitting for a fool.

2.verse: Like a bird that flits and flutters or a swallow in mid-flight, so a curse that lacks cause will never come to light.

3.verse: A whip is for the horse, a bridle is for the donkey, and a rod is for the fool’s back.

4.verse: Never answer a fool on his own foolish terms, or you will become like him;

5.verse: Rather, answer a fool on his own foolish terms, or he will become wise in his own eyes.

6.verse: Like someone who cuts off his feet or drinks to his ruin, so is the one who uses a fool to pass on his message.

7.verse: As lame legs are useless, dangling on the crippled, so is a proverb in the mouth of a fool.

8.verse: Like one who ties a stone in his slingshot, so is one who honors a fool.

9.verse: Like a thorn in the hand of a drunkard, so is a proverb in the mouth of a fool.

10.verse: Like an archer who shoots at random and injures everyone, so is a person who hires a fool or someone off the street.

11.verse: Like a dog who goes back to his own vomit, so is a fool who always returns to his foolishness.

12.verse: Have you seen a person who is wise in his own sight? Know that there is more hope for a fool than for him.

13.verse: A lazy person says, “There’s a lion in the road! A lion in the streets! Another good reason to stay in today.”

14.verse: As a door swings on its hinges and goes nowhere, so a slacker turns over in his bed.

15.verse: Some people are so lazy that they reach for food on the plate but lack the will to bring it up to their mouths.

16.verse: The slacker sees himself as wiser by far than seven men who can converse intelligently.

17.verse: Like a man who seizes a wild dog by the ears, so is anyone who walks by and meddles in someone else’s argument.

18.verse: Like a madman who hurls flaming spears and shoots deadly arrows,

19.verse: So is anyone who deceives a neighbor and then says, “But I was only joking with you.”

20.verse: When there is no wood, the fire goes out; when there is no one to spread gossip, arguing stops.

21.verse: Like charcoal to smoldering embers and dry wood to a fire, so a hot-tempered man kindles strife.

22.verse: Whispered gossip is like a delicious first course: it is devoured with pleasure and then penetrates deep within you.

23.verse: Like a shiny glaze coating a rough clay pot, so are burning lips that conceal an evil heart.

24.verse: One who hates may camouflage it beneath pleasant words, but deep inside him, treachery still rages;

25.verse: Don’t believe him when he speaks kindly because his heart is completely ruled by evil.

26.verse: And though he covers his hatred with cleverness, his wicked ways will be publicly exposed.

27.verse: The one who digs a trap for another will fall into it, and the one who starts rolling a stone will have it roll back over him.

28.verse: Liars take no pity on those they crush with their lies, and flattery spoils everyone it touches.

1.verse: Don’t brag about what may happen tomorrow because you have no idea what it will bring.

2.verse: Let someone else praise you; compliments are always sweeter from a stranger’s lips than from your own.

3.verse: Heavy is rock and weighty is sand, but more burdensome than either is the anger of a fool.

4.verse: Wrath is fierce and anger is a tidal wave of fury, but who of us can stand up against jealousy?

5.verse: Open rebuke is better than hidden love.

6.verse: Wounds inflicted by the correction of a friend prove he is faithful; the abundant kisses of an enemy show his lies.

7.verse: The person who is full has no interest in honey; but to the starving, bitterness itself is sweet.

8.verse: Like a bird that strays far from its nest, so is a person who forsakes his own home.

9.verse: The heart is delighted by the fragrance of oil and sweet perfumes, and in just the same way, the soul is sweetened by the wise counsel of a friend.

10.verse: Do not neglect your friend or your parent’s friend for that matter. When hard times come, you don’t have to travel far to get help from family; A neighbor who is near is better than a brother who is far away.

11.verse: Study to be wise, my son, and make my heart glad, for then your life will be my answer to anyone who hurls insults.

12.verse: The astute see evil coming and take shelter, but the stupid plow right on and then, of course, have to pay the price.

13.verse: If someone guarantees a stranger’s debt, hold his garment as collateral; if that guarantee is for the debt of a foreigner, make sure you get a deposit.

14.verse: Anyone who blesses his neighbor with a loud voice early in the morning, will find his blessing regarded as a curse.

15.verse: A constant dripping on a rainy day and a wife’s bickering are very much alike:

16.verse: Anyone who tries to control her might as well try to control the wind or pick up oil in his right hand.

17.verse: In the same way that iron sharpens iron, a person sharpens the character of his friend.

18.verse: Whoever takes care of a fig tree will eat of its fruit, and whoever cares for his master will be honored.

19.verse: Just as water reflects a person’s true face, so the human heart reflects a person’s true character.

20.verse: Neither the grave nor destruction is ever satisfied; the desires of people are never totally fulfilled.

21.verse: The crucible is used for refining silver, the furnace for gold, but praise is what tests a person’s mettle.

22.verse: Though you grind a fool like grain in a mortar with a pestle, still his foolishness will not be separated from him.

23.verse: Pay careful attention to your flocks, and see to the welfare of your herds

24.verse: Because riches do not last forever, nor does one dynasty retain power through all generations.

25.verse: When the hay is harvested and the autumn grasses begin to grow and the herbs of the mountains are gathered,

26.verse: Then the lambs will provide wool for your clothing, young goats can be sold to buy a new field,

27.verse: And there will be enough milk from your goats to sustain you, your family, and your serving girls.

1.verse: The wicked run away even when no one is chasing them; the right-living, however, stand their ground as boldly as lions.

2.verse: Where there is rebellion in a land, there are many petty and contending rulers; But where there is a wise and intelligent leader, peace and order endure.

3.verse: A poor person who oppresses others who are poor is like a driving rain that destroys the crops and leaves no food.

4.verse: Those who turn their backs on God’s teaching applaud the wicked, while those who observe His instruction oppose them at every turn.

5.verse: Evil people are not able to understand justice, but those who pursue the Eternal understand it completely.

6.verse: It is better to be a pauper walking in integrity than a dishonest man, even if he is rich.

7.verse: Whoever follows God’s teaching is a wise child, but the one who spends time with gluttons and drunks disgraces his parents.

8.verse: Anyone who increases his wealth by charging a high rate of interest is only collecting it for another who will deal more liberally with the poor.

9.verse: The one who turns his ear from hearing God’s instruction will find that even his prayers are detestable to God.

10.verse: Whoever tries to deceive a good person into taking the path of evil will fall into the pit he himself made, but the truly honest shall be the heirs of all that is good.

11.verse: A rich man may be wise in his own sight, but a perceptive pauper will see right through him.

12.verse: There is much glory when just men celebrate; but when the wicked gain power, people take cover.

13.verse: Whoever tries to hide his sins will not succeed, but the one who confesses his sins and leaves them behind will find mercy.

14.verse: Happy is the one who always fears the Lord, but the person who hardens his heart to God falls into misfortune.

15.verse: Like a roaring lion or a charging bear, so is a wicked man ruling over an impoverished people.

16.verse: A leader who lacks intelligence cruelly oppresses the people, but one who hates corruption will prosper and live a long life.

17.verse: A man guilty of murder is a fugitive, fleeing to the nearest hole in the ground but not escaping death’s cold pit. Don’t do anything to save him.

18.verse: Whoever walks in honesty will be safe, but whoever travels the crooked path will suddenly fall.

19.verse: Whoever cultivates his land will have plenty of food in the harvest, but whoever cultivates worthless ventures will have poverty in abundance.

20.verse: A reliable person will not escape blessings, but one who wants to get rich quick will not escape trouble.

21.verse: Showing favoritism is not good; some will desert the truth for a measly crust of bread.

22.verse: A greedy person is in a hurry to get rich, but he is ignorant of the loss that is about to overtake him.

23.verse: A person who offers constructive criticism will, in the end, be appreciated more than a person who engages in empty flattery.

24.verse: One who robs his father or his mother and says, “There’s nothing wrong with that! I had it coming!” walks in the company of murderers.

25.verse: When the greedy want more, they stir up trouble; but when a person trusts in the Eternal, he’s sure to prosper.

26.verse: Anyone who puts confidence only in himself is a fool, but the person who follows wisdom will be kept safe.

27.verse: Whoever gives to the poor will have what he needs, but the one who shuts his eyes to their plight will face curse after curse.

28.verse: When the wicked have the upper hand, people go into hiding; but when they perish, the good folk will begin to increase.

1.verse: The one who remains defiant after repeated reprimands will suddenly be shattered, and there will be no remedy for him.

2.verse: When just leaders are in power, the citizens celebrate; but when evil people gain control, their joys become moans.

3.verse: An adult who loves wisdom and follows its ways gives his parents joy, but one who hangs out with women of the street will lose everything.

4.verse: A king brings stability to a land with his justice, but one who makes unjust demands brings it to ruin.

5.verse: The one who flatters his friend is laying a trap that will catch his friend’s feet.

6.verse: An evil person is sure to be trapped by his sin, but a man who lives right is free to sing and be glad.

7.verse: The just get involved with the poor and know their issues, but the wicked cannot comprehend such concerns.

8.verse: Mockers stir up a city and inflame passions, but the wise know how to put out the fire and ease tensions.

9.verse: When the wise go to court against a fool, there will be ranting and raving but no resolution.

10.verse: Bloodthirsty men despise those who are honest, but the just find a way to help them.

11.verse: A fool does not think before he unleashes his temper, but a wise man holds back and remains quiet.

12.verse: When it is known that a ruler listens to the words of liars, soon he will have only scoundrels for advisors.

13.verse: A poor man and his oppressor have this in common: the Eternal created them and provides both with light and life.

14.verse: The king who is fair in his treatment of the poor will see his dynasty continue forever.

15.verse: Corporal punishment and correction produce wisdom, but a child left to follow his own willful way shames his mother.

16.verse: When evil people are free to flourish, sin is on the rise, but the just will surely see their destruction.

17.verse: If you discipline your children, they will make your life easier and refresh your soul.

18.verse: Where there is no vision from God, the people run wild, but those who adhere to God’s instruction know genuine happiness.

19.verse: Words are not enough to correct a servant; even if he understands, he will not respond.

20.verse: Have you ever met someone who is overly eager to talk? There is more hope for a fool than for him.

21.verse: If you indulge your servant from early in life, in the end it won’t go well for either of you.

22.verse: A hot-head provokes quarrels, and one mastered by anger commits all kinds of sins.

23.verse: A person’s pride brings him down, but one of humble spirit has a firm hold on honor and respect.

24.verse: Anyone who teams up with a thief must despise his own life, for he is bound by an oath to tell the truth and yet refuses.

25.verse: If you fear other people, you are walking into a dangerous trap; but if you trust in the Eternal, you will be safe.

26.verse: Many people vie for special treatment from a ruler, yet genuine justice proceeds from the Eternal.

27.verse: The right-living are disgusted by the actions of the unjust; likewise, the wicked are disgusted by the ways of the righteous.

1.verse: These are the words of Agur, son of Jakeh. An oracle of wisdom. He says, “I am weary, God. I am weary and spent, O God.”

2.verse: Certainly I am a stupid man, as dumb as an ox. I don’t understand the way that most people do.

3.verse: I have never learned wisdom, and I have no knowledge at all of the Holy One.

4.verse: Who has ascended into the heavens and then come back down? Who has collected the winds in the palm of His hand? Who has wrapped up the vast oceans in His coat? Who has plotted the ends of the earth and then fashioned them? What is His name? What is His son’s name? Do you know? Indeed, you do.

5.verse: The answer to all these questions, of course, is “no one but God.” Agur, like Job, understands the limits of human strength and knowledge. Unlike many, he freely confesses his need and takes refuge in the one True God. Every word of God will be put to the test and proven true; He is a defense for those who trust in Him.

6.verse: Take care. Add nothing to what He has said; for if you do, He will correct you and expose you as a liar.

7.verse: Two things I ask, O God. Sometime before I die, grant these humble requests:

8.verse: Eliminate any hint of worthless and deceitful words from my lips. Do not make me poor or rich, but give me each day what I need;

9.verse: For if I have too much, I might forget You are the One who provides, saying, “Who is the Eternal One?” Or if I do not have enough, I might become hungry and turn to stealing and thus dishonor the good name of my God.

10.verse: Wealth and poverty have something in common. Both situations can lead us to forget God. If we are rich, then it is easy to think it was our skill, our strength, and our hard work that got us there. We forget it was God who gave us the time and talent to succeed. If we are poor, then it is easy to steal and then make excuses for what we did. We forget that God said, “You are not to take what is not yours” (Exodus 20:15). When God’s people violate His teaching, God is the one who gets a black eye. Never run down a servant to his master because the slave might curse you and you would suffer as a result.

11.verse: There is a kind of person who curses his father and pronounces no blessing upon his mother;

12.verse: A kind of person who is without fault in his own estimation but has not been scrubbed clean of his own sordidness;

13.verse: A kind whose look is too haughty, whose eyebrows arch as he looks down on others;

14.verse: A kind whose very teeth cut like swords and whose jaws sever like knives, All the better to consume the poor of the earth and the oppressed among men.

15.verse: The leech has twin suckers; “More blood! More blood,” they demand. Three other things are just as insatiable, no, make it four that never say, “Enough”:

16.verse: The grave, the childless woman who cannot bear, the parched earth that cries for rain, and the fire, which never says, “Enough!”

17.verse: One who derides his father and fails to honor his mother in old age Will die in contempt: his eyes will be pecked out by the ravens of the valley and eaten by the young vultures when his unburied body lies on the trash heap.

18.verse: There are three mysteries I find absolutely amazing, no, make it four I cannot comprehend:

19.verse: The way an eagle flies through the sky, the way a snake moves over a rock, The way a boat glides through the middle of the sea, and the way a man becomes one with his virgin wife.

20.verse: An adulterous woman is so cavalier by nature. When she’s done, it is as if she washed after eating and then says, “I have done nothing wrong.”

21.verse: Three situations disturb the earth, no, make it four that it cannot endure:

22.verse: When a slave is elevated to king, when a fool is full of fine food,

23.verse: When a hated woman finally marries, and when a serving girl takes possession of her mistress’s wealth.

24.verse: There are four creatures on earth that are small, but they are very wise and we can learn from them:

25.verse: While ants are hardly a strong species, they work constantly to store up food during the summer;

26.verse: While badgers are animals without many defenses, they are wise enough to make their homes in the rocky cliffs;

27.verse: While locusts live without a ruler, they all know how to move in formation;

28.verse: While a lizard is easy enough to catch in your hand, it is shrewd enough to enter the palaces of kings.

29.verse: There are three creatures with majesty in their stride, no, make it four that move with grace:

30.verse: The lion, which is the strongest of the animals, does not back down from any other creature;

31.verse: The strutting rooster, the male goat, and a king as he goes out with his army.

32.verse: If you have been foolish enough to insinuate yourself in some high position or if you have concocted some sort of evil plan, clamp your hand tightly over your mouth;

33.verse: For pressing down milk makes butter, pressing your nose makes it bleed, and pressing anger makes trouble.

1.verse: These are the words of King Lemuel. An oracle of wisdom handed down to him by his mother:

2.verse: Mother: What shall I say to you, my son? What wisdom can I impart, child of my womb? What insight can I share, son of my vows?

3.verse: Do not waste your strength on women or invest yourself in women who would destroy even kings.

4.verse: Take care, my son, O Lemuel. Kings should not drink too much wine or rulers should not crave strong drink;

5.verse: For if they do, they will become drunk and forget the decree they just made and alter the course of justice for all the poor and afflicted.

6.verse: Rather, give liquor to one who is dying, and offer wine to those struggling with life’s harsh realities.

7.verse: Let such a one drink and forget what he is missing; then perhaps he won’t remember his sorrows anymore.

8.verse: Speak out on behalf of those who have no voice, and defend all those who have been passed over.

9.verse: Open your mouth, judge fairly, and stand up for the rights of the afflicted and the poor.

10.verse: King Lemuel’s mother warns him of the dangers of women and wine. In different ways, both have brought down great leaders. Both are certainly distractions to a king’s true work—defending the poor. Who can find a truly excellent woman? One who is superior in all that she is and all that she does? Her worth far exceeds that of rubies and expensive jewelry.

11.verse: She inspires trust, and her husband’s heart is safe with her, and because of her, he has every good thing.

12.verse: Every day of her life she does what is best for him, never anything harmful or hurtful.

13.verse: Delight attends her work and guides her fingers as she selects the finest wool and flax for spinning.

14.verse: She moves through the market like merchant ships that dock here and there in distant ports, finally arriving home with food she’s carried from afar.

15.verse: She rises from bed early, in the still of night, carefully preparing food for her family and providing a portion to her servants.

16.verse: She has a plan. She considers some land and buys it; then with her earnings, she plants a vineyard.

17.verse: She wraps herself in strength, carries herself with confidence, and works hard, strengthening her arms for the task at hand.

18.verse: She tastes success and knows it is good, and under lamplight she works deep into the night.

19.verse: Her hands skillfully place the unspun flax and wool on the distaff, and her fingers twist the spindle until thread forms.

20.verse: She reaches out to the poor and extends mercy to those in need.

21.verse: She is not worried about the cold or snow for her family, for she has clothed them all in warm, crimson coats.

22.verse: She makes her own bed linens and clothes herself in purple and fine cloth.

23.verse: Everyone recognizes her husband in the public square, and no one fails to respect him as he takes his place of leadership in the community.

24.verse: She makes linen garments and sells them in the market, and she supplies belts for tradesmen to carry across the sea.

25.verse: Clothed in strength and dignity, with nothing to fear, she smiles when she thinks about the future.

26.verse: She conducts her conversations with wisdom, and the teaching of kindness is ever her concern.

27.verse: She directs the activities of her household, and never does she indulge in laziness.

28.verse: Her children rise up and bless her. Her husband, too, joins in the praise, saying:

29.verse: “There are some—indeed many—women who do well in every way, but of all of them only you are truly excellent.”

30.verse: Charm can be deceptive and physical beauty will not last, but a woman who reveres the Eternal should be praised above all others.

31.verse: Celebrate all she has achieved. Let all her accomplishments publicly praise her. Marrying the right person is one of the most important decisions most people ever make, so they must choose wisely and carefully. The Book of Proverbs ends with a tribute to a wise choice in a wife. She is strong, independent, capable, and cares for her husband, her family, and the poor. She runs the whole household. In ancient Israel, this would mean a large extended family—including servants with all of their activities—and the family business. Her husband would sing her praises publicly before the community leaders. Those who know her would admire her for her skills, her industry, and her character.
